migrationGuide.title: Foundation: Line Endings and Hook Entry Point
migrationGuide.description: Configure .gitattributes for cross-platform line ending correctness and establish the canonical verify entrypoint before adding any checks. This prevents 'works locally, fails in CI' issues from day one.
migrationGuide.notes: Start here to avoid debugging cryptic CRLF failures later. Use .gitattributes as the authority for EOL (not .editorconfig). Run 'git add --renormalize .' after adding .gitattributes to fix existing files.

migrationGuide.title: Establish Local Safety Nets First
migrationGuide.description: Add pre-commit hooks with secret scanning, formatting, and linting. Hooks should CHECK (not auto-fix) and scope to changed files only for speed.
migrationGuide.notes: Keep hooks fast by scoping to staged files. Use Husky as entry point calling lint-staged or pre-commit. Hooks should check, not fix, to keep developers aware of issues.

migrationGuide.title: Mirror Local Checks in CI with CRLF Detection
migrationGuide.description: Introduce CI quality gates that mirror local hooks exactly. Add CRLF detection early in pipeline. Treat existing violations as warnings where possible.
migrationGuide.notes: CI must call the same verify scripts that hooks use. Add CRLF detection before other checks to fail fast on line ending issues. Use diff-based tools so only new violations break builds.

migrationGuide.title: Add Type Safety, Coverage, and Dependency Security
migrationGuide.description: Enable type-checking, coverage thresholds, and dependency/vulnerability scanning with gradual enforcement.
migrationGuide.notes: Pin tool and runtime versions in CI and containers to avoid flaky differences across environments.

migrationGuide.title: Layer in Docs, Governance, and Recommended Checks
migrationGuide.description: Add documentation standards, governance files, integration testing, performance baselines, complexity analysis, accessibility auditing, and (optionally) ML-specific practices for data-heavy Python repos.
migrationGuide.notes: Tackle recommended items in order of business value; backend-only repos can skip web-focused checks like accessibility.

migrationGuide.title: AI/ML Governance (If Applicable)
migrationGuide.description: For repos using or building with generative AI, add drift detection, schema enforcement, golden contract tests, safety testing, and provenance tracking.
migrationGuide.notes: Skip this step if your repo has no AI/ML components. For AI-heavy repos: add nightly drift detection to catch model changes, enforce strict schemas at AI output boundaries, and log provenance for debugging 'why did AI do X?'

core.label: Git Attributes (Line Endings)
core.description: Enforce line endings at the Git layer using .gitattributes. Mark text files with appropriate EOL handling (eol=lf for shell scripts, eol=auto for most files) and binary files as binary to prevent corruption. This prevents 'works locally, fails in CI' issues caused by CRLF/LF mismatches.

github-actions.notes: Add .gitattributes check as first step in CI job.

stack.notes: Python files should use LF endings for cross-platform compatibility. Mark *.py as eol=lf in .gitattributes. Shebang scripts fail with CRLF.
stack.verification: Run 'git ls-files --eol' and verify Python files use LF.

machineCheck.description: Verify no CRLF in Python files

core.label: CRLF Detection in CI
core.description: Fail CI early for Linux-executed files containing CRLF line endings. Shell scripts, Python files, and other interpreted files fail silently or with cryptic errors when they contain \r characters. Detect this before running deeper CI steps.

github-actions.notes: Add CRLF detection step before main CI steps.

stack.notes: Python shebang scripts fail with CRLF. Check all .py and .sh files for CRLF before running pytest or other Python tools.
stack.verification: Run CRLF detection on Python and shell files.

core.label: Git and Docker Ignore Files
core.description: Maintain proper .gitignore and .dockerignore files to prevent committing secrets, build artifacts, or unnecessary files.

stack.notes: Use the official github/gitignore Python template. Include **pycache**, .venv/, .pytest_cache, .env, and similar local-only files. .dockerignore must exclude .git, virtual environments, and caches.
stack.verification: .gitignore must exist; .dockerignore is recommended when containerizing or using Docker workflows.

core.label: Semantic Versioning
core.description: Use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH versioning with clear rules and automated changelog generation based on commit history. Maintain a single canonical version source (for example, package.json or VERSION) that all release artifacts use.

stack.notes: Automate version bumping and changelog generation using setuptools_scm (git-tag based) or bumpversion with towncrier for changelog fragments. Keep pyproject.toml (or VERSION) as the single canonical version source, and have CI publish GitHub/PyPI/Docker artifacts from that same version.

core.label: Version Guard (Automated Releases)
core.description: If semantic-release or automated versioning is enabled, block manual edits to canonical version fields in pull requests. Enforce a CI guard (and optional pre-push hook) that fails when version lines change outside the release workflow.

stack.notes: Block manual edits to version fields in pyproject.toml or setup.cfg when automated release tooling computes versions from commit history.

core.label: Release Artifact Formatter Exclusion
core.description: Exclude auto-generated release artifacts (CHANGELOG.md, package-lock.json, etc.) from code formatters to prevent CI failures. Release automation tools generate files that may not conform to your formatter's style, causing format checks to fail on subsequent CI runs.

github-actions.notes: Ensure format:check step uses ignore file that excludes release artifacts.

core.description: Release automation must bypass local developer hooks (HUSKY=0, --no-verify) and rely solely on CI gates for validation. This ensures idempotent, reproducible releases that don't fail due to hook environment differences.

core.label: Pre-Commit Hooks
core.description: Use git hooks to run linting, formatting, and commit linting before changes are committed. Hooks should CHECK by default (not auto-fix), be fast, and scope to changed files only. Use a single entry hook mechanism (e.g., Husky as entry point calling pre-commit or lint-staged).
